Dear Barry

I am sorry, but I don't recall seeing the images of your Namban=
 tsuba 
before and I am unable to find them in my 'in box'.  Is a green pap=
er 
from the NBTHK 35 years ago the equivalent of a tokubetsu kicho paper 
=
(or perhaps it has just turned green with age!)

Namban tsuba are incredibl=
y difficult to photograph, and this 
difficulty is compounded when the meta=
l is dark.  A tsuba of this 
group with a plano-convex profile is very unus=
ual - I have certainly 
never seen one.  It has the ubiquitous, symmetrical=
 design of 
affrontes dragons facing the tama jewel (or is it a lotus bloss=
om?, 
with lashings of gold overlay.  The alternating, perforated design 
i=
nside the mimi is a commonly found one, as is the chryanthemoid 
mimi.  Int=
erestingly, the seppa-dai is only gilded on the omote 
surface - I sometime=
s wonder how well would the seppa sit on a seppa-
dai such as this.  The ko=
dzuka-hitsu is clearly a later addition.

The photographs are much too dark=
 to enable any deatailed assessment 
of the carving and undercutting, but i=
t appears to be of quite good 
quality.

Date?  Who am I to argue with 1670=
, but that seems to be a pretty 
exact attribution.  Perhaps I would put it=
 rather later - what does 
the kanteisho say?

Regards, John.

--- In nihon=
tostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Barry Thomas" <warlord@...> 
wrote:
>
> Dear All,=

> 
> Whilst we are on the topic of Namban tsuba I have posted two (not 
so=
 good) images of my Namban tsuba that took a green paper at the 
first NBTH=
K Shinsa in the USA mmm maybe 35 years ago.  The obverse 
(red background) =
is convex whilst the reverse (green background) is 
flat.  A polisher visit=
ing once commented "a good one!!".  Early Edo 
period ca 1670, I believe.
>=
 
> Oh, it's in my folder "Barry Thomas" third one on the first page 
(sorr=
y, no tiny url.  Something else I have to learn how to do!).  
John I think=
 I sent you these images quite some while ago???
> 
> Best regards,
> 
> Ba=
rry Thomas.
